content.description: Z Elephant Boy has steep climbing on good holds. Start right of the first bolt and traverse in. This is a strenuous and fun route.
content.protection: 5 bolts to top anchors with Mussy hooks. All hardware was replaced Sept. 2020 with SS glue-ins thanks to San Luis Valley Climbers Alliance and ASCA. Note, the anchors were repositioned down on the face to avoid the hollow rock on top where the chains used to be.
content.location:
From

When the Wives are Away

belay platform, walk over the large, downed tree to climber's left. You enter a shady, cool alcove. The climb is in the back and is obvious.

content.description: This is a well-protected line for new climbers or wives recovering from childbirth! It has easy climbing to the halfway point then a bit of a crux which eases off the further up you go until you finish on jugs. Stay left of the bolts for the most part.
content.location:
Just left of the

Left Mixed 9

, scramble up on the platform made by the big, dead tree stump. An awesome belay lounge chair can be had on the cantilevered rock pointing out from the wall.

content.description: Right 10 is kind of technical off the ground and pumpy at the top with some bouldery terrain in between. You probably want to start a little right of the first bolt unless you stick clip it.
content.protection: 6 bolts with chains over the top.
content.location:
It is the rightmost sport route on the cliff, right next to

Damnifiknow

.

content.description:
Start off with a short scramble up to a ledge with a no-hands rest. Climb a technical ramp, and then get a quick shake before tackling the powerful overhanging face (crux). I went left, probably making it slightly easier.

Be careful, a few loose hand/footholds from time to time. Until this thing cleans up a bit more, I could see the grade changing quite a bit.
content.location:
When you get to the Little Black Cliff, turn sharp left, and walk past

When The Wives Are Away...

. The rock will dip back away from the road creating a tree-filled clearing. This is on the far side next to

Z Elephant Boy

.

content.description:
This is an interesting route that wanders around some trashy rock before an engaging finish.

Be careful clipping the bolt off the ankle breaker ledge as you enter the business.
content.protection: 7 bolts and chains over the top.
content.location:
It is about 15 feet left of

Headwaters of Denial

.

content.description:
Climb the dihedral. You might be able to use the anchors on the

Left Mixed 9

to the left.
content.location:
This climbs the right-facing dihedral which is the left side of the inset area left of

Middle 11

.

content.description:
This route has easy climbing protected with 5 bolts to anchors with rap rings.

Your belayer should wear a helmet. It is a new route, and some of the holds seem ready to break off.
content.location:
It is the 2nd route right of

Z Elephant Boy

.

content.description: Climb a face with a few thin moves. An occasionally tricky piece of pro keeps potential falls from getting long. Well-placed bolts supplement the gear.
content.protection: Mixed with 3 bolts and gear. There are chains at the top.
content.location:
From

Middle 11

, go left about 20 feet past the kind-of-inset area with the opposing diehedrals. This is on the right side of the next buttress.

content.description:
This is protected with 5 bolts to anchors with chains.

The beginning moves are easy and lead to a shallow overhang, which may intimidate beginners. From there, the holds are less obvious.

Your belayer should wear a helmet. We broke off a pretty large hold (head-sized).
content.location:
This route is 3 or 4 climbs right from

Z Elephant Boy

.

content.description: This has a technical move in the middle and a pumpy finish.
content.protection: 6 bolts with quicklinks and chains at the anchor. All bolts are SS glue-ins as of Oct. 2019 thanks to San Luis Valley Climbers Alliance and ASCA.
content.location: It is the second sport route from the right side of the cliff.

content.description:
This is a fun route that shares anchors with

Loose and Dubious

. A handful of bolts gets you to the top.
content.location:
It is directly right of

Loose and Dubious

and shares its anchors.

content.description:
This is a nice route for beginner trad climbers or for kids. There is a little bit of a crux about 2/3 height, and there are plenty of rests.

This route is also a fun little mixed line in the winter, with the same name (M4).
content.protection: Single set of nuts and cams. There are camoflauged Metolius shuts at the top on the right. These are accessible for top roping with care.
content.location: It ascends a chimney-like line of weakness on right side of the cliff.

content.description:
This route is around the corner from

When The Wives Are Away...

. This is a fun arete. It is protected by 4 bolts to the top.
content.location:
This climb is left around the corner from

When The Wives Are Away...

.

content.description: This is kind of an easy, mellow climb.
content.protection: Bolts to chains anchor. It is hard to access the anchor for toproping.
content.location:
It ascends the buttress left (around the corner) of

Z Elephant Boy

.

content.description:
This is the line of bolts on the arete crowded in between the

Buttress Climb

and

Z Elephant Boy

. The route seems contrived and way too close to the

Buttress Climb

which overlaps for the first few bolts. It is either a contrived variation or a contrived attempt to establish a hard route right on the arete even as the easier holds just left make you trend that way. Bolt 1 is in an awkward position, and a stickclip is recommended. I'm not sure which anchors -

Buttress Climb

or

Z Elephant Boy

were intended as the finish. Both are runout, and both incur rope drag for belaying the second. Speaking of the second, this line puts your second in a crappy situation if they fall.
content.protection: 5 bolts - installed with mixed metal (plated steel wedge bolts, SS hangers) so it's just a matter of time before it needs to be replaced.
